settings.specialized__what_content:
Thyroid disease is when your Thyroid gland either produces too much or too little Thyroid hormone.

Your Thyroid gland is responsible for regulating major functions in your body like brain development, metabolism, and much more.

Thyroid disease is often broken down into three unique conditions: Hyperthyroidism, Hypothyroidism, and Hashimoto's disease.

settings.heading: Why and How Does Thyroid Disease Cause Hair Loss?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
Those dealing with any form of Thyroid Disease (Hyperthyroidism, Hypothyroidism, and Hashimoto's Disease) may experience hair loss. While not all those diagnosed with these conditions will experience hair loss, it still is a prominent symptom across the board.

The reason hair loss often reported is because when T3 and T4 hormone production is effected, it often impacts other main functions of the body. This includes regulating your metabolism, heart rate, and new hair growth.

What actually occurs when you notice your hair loss is actually not that you are necessarily losing more hair than you normally would without a Thyroid condition. Instead, because the hormone is disrupted, it's new growth that is mostly effected.

We all lose hair, but typically our hair loss is replaced by new growth. When the natural hair fall is not replaced with new growth, that's when we see hair thinning. This can happen on the scalp as well as the eyebrows.

settings.heading: What is a thyroid gland and where is it located?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans: Your thyroid gland is a small butterfly-shaped organ located at the bottom of your neck.

settings.heading: What is the thyroid gland responsible for?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans: The thyroid gland is a hormone gland that is a part of your endocrine system. It helps regulate vital functions such as metabolism, growth, and body development and can also affect heart rate, temperature, digestive function, brain development, and more.

settings.heading: What is Hyperthyroidism?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
Hyperthyroidism is a condition that occurs when your thyroid gland produces too much of the Thyroid hormone, thyroxine. This impacts your heart (palpitations), metabolism, and can make you feel anxious or nervous.

Hyperthyroidism causes include Graves' disease, Plummer's disease and Thyroiditis. It can be serious if left untreated and it is important to consult a physician if you suspect you have Hyperthyroidism.

settings.heading: What Are Hyperthyroidism Symptoms?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
• nervousness, jitteriness, anxiety and irritability
  • difficulty sleeping
  • persistent tiredness and weakness
  • sensitivity to heat
  • a goitre (Thyroid gland becomes large and swollen. It is often noted as a large swelling that is visible on your neck)
  • heart rate (palpitations)
  • twitching or trembling
  • weight loss

settings.heading: What is Hypothyroidism?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
Hypothyroidism is a medical condition that occurs when your Thyroid gland does not produce enough Thyroid hormone. It is also known as a underactive Thyroid. Your Thyroid gland is responsible for regulating your body's metabolic rate which controls your heart, muscle, digestive functions, and brain development.

In its early stages, Hypothyroidism can be very difficult to diagnose as the symptoms vary from person to person and can initially be very subtle. However there are a few hypothyroid signs you can look out for:

settings.heading: What Are Hypothyroid Symptoms?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
• tiredness
  • sensitivity to cold
  • weight gain
  • constipation
  • depression
  • loss of train of thought (brain fog)
  • muscle aches, cramps, and weakness
  • dry skin
  • brittle hair / hair loss
  • brittle and/or peeling nails
  • irregular periods or heavy periods (in women)

settings.heading: What is Hashimoto's Disease?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans: Hashimoto's Disease (also known as Hashimoto's Thyroiditis) is an autoimmune disease. It occurs when the immune system creates antibodies that attack the thyroid gland and causes the thyroid to produce too little thyroid hormone. It is the most common cause of Hypothyroidism.

settings.heading: What Are Hashimoto's Symptoms?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
• fatigue
  • sensitivity to cold
  • constipation
  • dry skin
  • brittle nails
  • hair loss
  • weight gain
  • muscle aches and pains
  • brain fog

settings.heading: What is Graves Disease?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans: Graves Disease is an autoimmune disease that causes the thyroid gland to produce too much thyroid hormone, resulting in Hyperthyroidism.
